Transliteration:
1. [E2.GAL {m}]10#-ERIM.TAḪ2 UGULA#
2. [A GID2]-DI#-DINGIR UGULA-ma
3. [ša2] ki#-si-ir-ti
4. [ša2] IGI# ID2
Translation: [The palace of] Adad-nārārī, overseer, [son of Arik]-dīn-ili (who was) also overseer: (brick) [belonging to] the facing (of the quay wall) [which] fronts onto the River (Tigris).
Philological remarks: Inscription on the side: E2#.GAL {m}10-ERIM#.TAḪ2# MAN# [KIŠ] "(property of) the palace of Adad-nārārī, king [of the universe]"
General remarks: 19 brick exemplars published, 2 of which found in situ (Miglus 2010: 234).

Translation: The palace of Adad-nārārī, overs[eer], son of Arik-dīn-ili (who was) also overseer: (brick) belonging to the facing (of the quay wall) [wh]ich fronts onto the River (Tigris).

Transliteration:
1. [E2.GAL {m}10]-ERIM#.TAḪ2# [UGULA]
2. [A GI]D2-DI-DING[IR] UGULA-m[a]
3. ša2 [ki-si-ir]-ti
4. ša2# [IG]I ID2#
Translation: [The palace of Adad]-nārārī, [overseer, son of Ar]ik-dīn-il[i] (who was) als[o] overseer: (brick) belonging to the [fa]cing (of the quay wall) which [fro]nts onto the River (Tigris).

Transliteration:
1. {d}sul#-ge
2. nita# kal-ga#
3. lugal# uri5#[{ki}]-ma#
4. lugal a[n-u]b[a-da] limmu2#-b[a]
Translation: Divine Šulgi, mighty man, king of Ur, king of the fo[ur qua]rters.
General remarks: A standard stamped inscription of Šulgi arranged in one column of 4 lines. Bricks like these were excavated in several places in southern Mesopotamia, primarily Ur, but also Nippur and others. This brick is similar to a batch of four bricks of Šulgi published by Radner (2011), acquired by the museum in March 2010. Based on Radner's commentary the use of the divine determinative in Šulgi's name and his royal title would date this brick at least from his 20th regnal year onwards (inscriptions of this kind were introduced in his 26th year). Radner further suggests that bricks with this stamp come from Tell al-Wilāyah, possibly ancient Kesh. This fits well to another Ur III brick of Šū-Sîn (B758) analysed with this batch, that have a parallel in the site.

Transliteration:
1. E2.GAL {m}GIŠ.[tukul-ti]-{d}#nin#-urta
2. MAN# [KIŠ A {d}sal2-ma-n]u-MAŠ
3. [MAN KIŠ]-ma#
Translation: The palace of [Tukultī]-Ninurta, king of the [universe, son of Shalman]eser (I) (who was) also [king of the universe].
General remarks: Numerous parallel inscribed bricks mostly found at Assur (Miglus 1985: 31-39), but also at Nineveh, Kar-Tukulti-Ninurta (Tulul al-ʿAqir), and Šibaniba (Tell Billa, Baasheikhah).

Transliteration:
1. [E2].GAL# {m}#10#-[ERIM.TAḪ2 MAN KIŠ]
2. [A] GID2#-DI#-[DINGIR MAN KUR aš-šur]
3. ša2# ki#-si#-ir#-ti#
4. [ša2] KA#-i na-ar#-ti#
5. [ša2 E2].GAL-la#-ti#
Translation: The palace of Adad-nārārī, king of the universe, son of Arik-dīn-ili, king of Assyria: (brick) belonging to the facing (of the quay wall) at the mouth of the canal of the palace complex.
General remarks: 5 line inscription, one of the known exemplars was found in situ in the quay wall. Work on this wall is described in another inscription from Assur (RIMA 1 A.0.76.11: http://oracc.org/riao/Q005748/).

Transliteration:
1. E2.GAL
2. Ia-ku-un-di-ri
3. DUMU Su-ma/ta-nim
4. LUGAL ma-at
5. Hu-ur-ši-tim
Translation: Palace of Iakūn-dīri son of Suma/tanim, king of the land Huršitum.
Philological remarks: Reading of king name and title made by Wagensonner
General remarks: An unparalleled inscription of Iakūn-dīri son of Sumanim(?), a king of Huršitum. In the royal corpus he is only known from a seal of his servant Iamūt-Kuluh (RIME E4.0.11). His kingdom had another monarch named Pūhīya son of Asīrum, who has a stamped brick that was found near Tūz Ḥurmati where the Aqsu river crosses the Jebel Ḥamrīn. Iakūn-dīri is well attested in the Mari corpus, and is a contemporary of Zimrī-Līm.
